UPDATED: MAY 23, 2009 50cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Batch 237. Bottled 2006-03-12. Best before 2011-03-12. It poured a dark brown colour with a big foamy head that settles down nicely in the glass. The aroma is sweet and smells of dark caramel, spices and sweet malts. Like the aroma, the flavour is spicy and also tastes of dark caramel, sweet malts. Theres also some notes of weak coffee, dark berries and some alcohol. It has a lingering aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2008 Interesting beer. Aromatic hoppy taste and with chocolate, toffee and fudge. I hope I will get the chance to try this again. Another fantastic brew from one of Scandinavias best breweries!

Update: This beer is almost perfect. I mean, this is so... everything is so delicous. Im excited. Best one from Nøgne Ø. Perfection. Taste is so excellent and mouthfeel is so thick. I love it. I have four bottles left at home. I hope I can save them for a while, but Im not sure I manage to not drink it before the summer.


Update, again: This is definitely one of the best beers from Nøgne Ø. Aroma of chocolate, fudge and some hops. Flavour is quite sweet and malty with notes of fudge, chocolate, toffee, roasted malt and aromatic hops. Palate is very, very smooth and the liquid is quite thick. Really cool beer! Though I’ve had better ones from Nøgne Ø... maybe I got a bit tired on this one after drinking 5-6 bottles in a few months this spring?

bottle 500ml 12euros at Opus K Lohja
Color.dark brown bit hazy, bit foam and lace
scent:sweet hops
taste: brown sugar sweet, complex mixture of hops and sweetnes

Bottle 0,5l. Dark brown colored with a light brown head. Strong spicy aroma. The head reduced itself to a thin layer. Soft mouthfeel. Complex aroma of smoke and fruit. A flavor that grows in your mouth. Caramellish impression with fruity hints and an aftertaste that lasts forever. Wonderful. A lot of sediments.

This is just rated to get the average score, and for me to know i have tasted it. But need to re taste it. Tasted this a few days ago an something was wrong with it. It had a strong metallic aroma/taste.

500ml bottle (batch 237 - brewed in March 06). Dark rusty brown body resting under an one-finger, light brownish head. Impressive potpourri of aromas and flavours. Spicy smell with hints of liquorice, chocolate and dark fruits. The taste brings bread, earth, and woody dryness up front with a moderate tartness of dark fruits and berries (blackcurrant) behind. Details of herbs and mould cheese to follow. Developing bitterness towards the end mixed with a touch of yeast and warmth from the alcohol. Enjoyed for one and a half hour. Perfect as a late nightcap on a dark xmas night (25.12.2007).
Heavy hoppy and smoked aroma. Huge, light brown initial flavor. Excellent lacing. Clear amber body. Moderate bitter, smoked and coffee notes flavor. Medium palate.

Bottle (50 cl) from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, Denmwrk. Deep reddish brown with a huge beige head. Caramelly, nutty and slightly roasted malt aroma, earthy and floral hops, and a clear touch of alcohol. Medium bodoed with a spritzy carbonation. Initially sweet but after a while a long-lasting bitterness appears.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a big tan head. Malty aroma with notes of dark fruits & nuts. Malty, bready taste mostly. Sweet finish.

0.5 l bottle. Reddish brown color with tan head. Sweet and roasted aroma with raisins, chocolade and port wine. The flavor is also sweet, chocolatey and vinous with notes of rum, sharp alcohols and some astringency. Too strong carbonation. Nice port wine aroma and flavor.

Bottled at the Mikkeller tasting.  Poured clear copper with a swirly dusting of beige head.  The aroma had a very nice caramelization to it with toasty caramel and semi-sweet chocolate accented by herbal notes.  The flavor was of semi-sweet chocolate and toasty caramel at the base with peppery notes, faint cardboard, and herbal bitterness.. prickly alcohol at the end.  Somewhat oxidized and prickly on the palate.. about medium-bodied.  Solid beer that has probably seen better days.

Norwegian labeled bottle.  The beer pours to a glowing fire red hued brown body with a thin light tan head.  The aroma is nougat, Belgian yeasts, light chocolate.  The flavor is chocolatey brown ale with sweet honey or other sugars.  Creamy tastes.  The palate is sweet and drying with a nice medium mouthfeel.

Pours an extremely dark, impenetrable chestnut with violet and crimson hues at the perimeter. A beige head is thick, creamy and very slowly diminishing. Lacing is thick and almost fully covering. The aroma is very nutty and pleasantly lactic, fresh cream nuances parading within the confines of the open space inside the top portion of the snifter. A blend of caramel nougat, chocolate syrup and bitter cocoa powder follow, then peanut oil, toffee bricks, spicy and grassy hops, mild hints of soy and overprocessed/overutilized sugars. Alcohol is moderate to heavy. Im finding that most beers from this brewery seem to make no effort to conceal alcohol. The flavor is not as exciting or palatable as the nose indicated. Malt is primarily toasted, some roasted beyond that. Nutty character is accellerated. Lactic acidity and spice are ever-growing. Chocolate sweetness quickly turns dusty and barren. Hints of soil rifle the tastebuds into slumbering submission. A mild astringency dices through the hop resins, then the malt. The finish is nutty, slowly drying, turbulent, lightly to moderately warming, with lingering caramel, milk chocolate and peanut. Grassiness is very strong and fresh throughout the experience but never feels overtly "green". The mouthfeel is adequately carbonated(sometimes a touch fizzy), has watery pockets but for the most part is medium-full bodied, stuttered in its flow and spicy/biting/pseudo-tannic. Uninteresting, pretty easy to drink.

Bouteille de 500 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de caramel légèrement fumé. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque. Présence dun mince col beige et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de figues. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de caramel fumé en arrière goût. (Rating #1268)

(Bottle, Haket, Gothenburg, 1 Aug 2007) Very dark brown colour with frothy beige head. Frutiy, malty nose with coffee, chococlate and citrussy hops. Taste starts malty with notes of chocolate and cocoa, turns fruitier with notes of citrussy hops and grapefruit. Finishes with a lovely balance between chocolate and citrussy hops. Lovely beer.

Near black colored with red hints, medium sized beige head. Extremely rich aroma: chocolate, licorice, vinous touch with some berries, excellent one. Medium bodied, could be fuller. Flavor is also rich, roastiness is more obvious than in aroma, toffee and caramel there in start too. Ending turns to strongly hopped and dry, still some vinous alcoholic tone there with even some vanilla. Again excellent and complex brew fron Nogne, aroma is world class.
Bottle. Large head. Dark brown color. Fulle body. Heavy malt, notes of caramel. Very nice
Bottle. Dark brown colour with medium creamy off-white mostly diminishing head. Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate. Sweet flavor with bitter finish. Oily palate.
Dark brown and cloudy, head is light brown, large and lasting. Aorma is dark, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is heavy sweet, bitter. Texture is dry, syrup.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Brown colour. Moderate malty and heavy hopy aroma. Really nice. Moderate bitter flavor. Average moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate. Really nice beer.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 500ml bottle (SOPP2007, Helsinki)
Very dark brown, beige head. Aroma very sweet, some cigarette butts. Becomes browner, i.e. maltier, over time. Taste is also sweet, a bit alcoholic, sticky malty taste. Tiny bit of marmite hinted at too. Very full taste - excellent. (7-4-8-3-14=3.6)
Rerate at HBF2008: Malty, fruity, rye, sweet, powerful, succulent. Wow!

Bottle @ SOPP, Helsinki. Dark red, small beige head. Aroma of pine, pineapple, orange, cloves. Very full aroma iondeed. Bubbles up in your mouth. Taste creamy, continues well on the same theme as in the aroma.

Bottled (brygget 12.03.06 batch #237)
Dark hazy nut brown color, steady creamy expresso head. Chocolate, toasted malts, toffee, coffee, yeast and some sticky hops. Chocolaty, toffee-fudge caramelly, yeasty. Medium to full bodied. Sweet, slightly alcoholic beer with liquerish palate and some hoppy peak in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2008 (Bottled) Almost clear, reddish dark brown cola color with a large, tanned and bubbly head. Very malty and caramely, lightly roasty, dark-toffeeish aroma with anise hints. Sweet-sticky-malty, nutty-hoppy, fruity and anisey flavor with roasty maltiness. Quite full-bodied, sticky and low-carbonated palate. A very enjoyable dessert drink with lots of Belgian influences. Sweetness is on the limit, but still I love this!

In the bottle at the Max & Joes Belgian Beer Tasting. Thanks for the beer mdi! Pours a rich-colored brown with a dense tan head. This beer has a deep nutty caramel toasted molasses aroma. It just smells thick! A super sweet beer. Its like drinking a glass of silky smooth butterscotch and chocolate milk. WOW!!!

Fantastic complex aroma of roasted malt, raisins and hops, but lacks some fruitiness from the yeast according to my palate. Very warming in the mouth, well attenuated and stiff bitter backing. But the alcohol is a bit too dominant in the finish. Not an ale for quaffing, but a nice nightcap.

Bottle.  [Thanks to Papsoe for sharing!]  Large creamy beige head that mostly lasted. Good display of lacework. Cloudy almost mahogany color. Aroma of bread, caramel, roasted malt, nutty, grass, light grapefruit and a mix of fruity notes as well. Medium to full bodied with a soft carbonation and somewhat oily and at the same time sticky light alcoholic texture. Moderated sweet malty flavor with light to moderated bitter notes. Balanced but the oily and dry like bitterness wins in the end. 08-07-2007

From 50 cL bottle. Pours hazy brown with a red hue. Light brown creamy head. Aroma is malty sweet and dried fruit. Liqourice, sweet malty and slight bitter flavoured. Liqourice and bitterness makes the finish. Very nice.

(Bottle 50 cl) Hazy, reddish brown with a dense, beige head leaving laces. Fat, nutty nose. Rather full-bodied with lots of nuts and burned caramel - and also an edge of burned malt. The finish is dry and bitter. 080707
Light brown, minimal head.  Aroma is sugary brown and salty.  Sweet, sugary flavour with a touch of spice.  Almost Belgian triple-like. A touch sugary on the finish.

[Sampled at DØE-festival, Valby, 2007 with svoger.]
What a dream. A mix of two of my favorite styles. Fruits (dried) and hoppyness for a long, long, long lasting flavor. Must buy it to enjoy alone!

Plenty of milk chocolate is notable in the sweet, malty, nutty aroma along with a light roasty undertone.  Opaque brown body is toped by a generous and lasting tan head that recedes slowly to cover with some sudsy lace.  Sweet and nutty chocolate flavour with plenty of residual sugars.  Roasty darker malts offer counterpoint and moderate bitterness cuts off the sugar before it becomes cloying.  Medium full body with soft bubbled effervescence and creamy texture.  Bottle sampled with BeerPrince, CapFlu, and Oakes.

(Bottle) Sampled at a TiggMTL tasting in Vancouver on June 30, 2007. Lasting tan, creamy head with a cloudy brown body. Nose of fresh figs, malt and marshmellow. Nicely bitter and good hop appearance backed by roasted malt. Very enjoyable.

Murky flattish brown. Looks absolutely terrible. Rather fudgey aroma with lots of sugars.  Sweet flavour, again quite fudgey, a little nutty and with a hint of chocolate.  Flavours are muddled though, not bright, and the whole thing is way too sweet.  Nothing comes together and Im not sure Id care if it did.

(Bottle)  Pours a dark mahogany body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of baked molasses, prunes, nuts, and cocoa.  Flavor of toasted malt, dark fruit, toffee, and vinous with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel.
Bottle, batch 237. This is the very first time I try it. Reminds me a little bit of NØ#100, but this one is not as full-bodied

Bottle. Pours a muddy dark brown with a big and creamy yellowish off white head.Aroma is great - lots of sweet chocolate with a roasted edge to it. A vinious flavour is dominant, but still gives room to caramel and lots of sweet, light chocolate. A touch of smoke as well and a very mild bitterness.

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Clear medium brown color with a large frothy good lacing mostly lasting light-brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, burnt, caramel, light alcohol, vintage. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic.
Bottle at CPH festival. Dark brown with creamy full brown head. Sweet caramel malty aroma - nice. Smooth, full & creamy. Pleasant & easy drinkable and very nice. Light oily palate.

Bottle (500ml).  Via trade with Boutip.  Very deep, near-opaque brown-red, average foamy tan head.  Mild roast malt, caramel-sweet, strong notes of tea, raspberry and cherry - milky.  Very tart and bitter - strong bittering hops and tons of raspberry here, acidic and slightly boozy.  Watery body, not much life to it, a touch syrupy - interesting, odd, love the tartness but it sort of kills the roast.

Bottle at Nørrebro Bryghus, Copenhagen. This is NB´s big sister. I tasted both beers at NB, and there is little doubt that Nøgne Øs version is in a higher division. I will re-test this next time I´m in Copenhagen.
Dark brown with a thick tan head. Lots of caramel and hoppy notes. Malty with chocolate taste. Full bodied with a long, dry finish.
Bottle at Chris_O bottlefest 2007.  Brown colour with tan head.  A load of US hops over a reasonable but very malty brown ale.  Bit unsubtle.

Dark ruby body with a medium tan head.  Voluptuously malted body exhibiting a dark cake flavour.  Taste of chocolate is halfway between milk-chocolate and dark chocolate.  Fruity notes of blackberries and dark cherries.  Mixing the sumptuous malted body with the chocolate and fruity flavours really makes you feel like youre drinking a cake.  Leafy hops add a surprising orange flavour to the mix.  Super nice mature beer that doesnt need additional work.  It feels like they really dotted the is and crossed the ts on this one and in the case of Nøgne, crossed the øs too.
ChrisFest Sweet, sweet, sweet - yet also quite mild and pleasant. A strong mild ale - a stronger version of the bottled milds of Southern England that were called Brown Ale.

A Mes rate: 50cl bottle at Chris O’s extravaganza. Jolly good. Not too impressed with the nose but the falvour is great. A lovely balance of chewy malt and crisp leafy hops. Palate is typically excelent from this brewer. Nice beer.

Dark brown color, with a rocky tan-colored head, leaving laces, toasted malt nose, with a nutty accent, cookie dough, hint of nutmeg spiciness, toffeeish note, subtle licorice, faint flowery hop in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet toasted malt character, with a dark bitter chocolatey note, a floral hop leafiness, brown sugar, hint of roasted coffee beans, a bit spicy, maybe licorice, leading towards a malty, dry hops bitterness finish.

Bottled at Chris_O Fest March 2007.  A dark brown coloured beer with a beige coloured head.  The aroma is very American stylee with big hops and lovely malts.  This continues into the taste.  THe sweetness from the malts tends to dominate but its very tasty. More an American Strong than a Brown Ale really.

Bottle. Thanks to Beer_2000 for this treat. Pours dark ruby with a  modest tan head. Tempting sweet malt aroma with  caramel, mild coffee, hazelnut and fresh hops. Bittersweet taste; roasty malts, toffee/caramel,  with a proper citric acidicy. Oily mouthfeel, strong body. Long , slight bitter coffeeish finish. Nøgne Ø is top end!

Wow...I do believe that I am the first from the States to rate this one.  Many thanks to Maria, the Grand Dame of Beer. Nose is of roses and passionfruit      Pours a Dark brown with ruby tones as the light hits the glass.  Sticky lacing and small consistent head.  Sweet frothy body that is substantial in flavor and duration.  Hops are gentle and well balanced.  A fine brew
Robe brune foncée surmontée dune mousse brune épaisse en dentelle qui persiste. Arômes de caramel, de café et de chocolat. Saveurs de caramel, de chocolat, de houblon amérisant et de torréfié.

rbesg06gt, bottled. dark brown but not dull colour with a steady light brown head. aroma of raisin, cocoa powder, toasted marshmallows. plenty of flavour - licorice, hazelnut, coffee with an earthy dry finish. pretty classy stuff

Bottle: Poured a deep brown color ale with a huge medium brown color head with good retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel malt with some buts and light hops is very interesting. Taste is maltier then expected with huge caramel malt with some nuts. The finish is slightly bitter but less then expected for an Imperial brown ale; it appear that the imperial is related to the malt as opposed to the hops which is quite interesting. Body is above average with some medium carbonation. Overall, I would say that this was a well done beer  in what is often a boring style.

Comments: Firm palate from its beefy malts with a well detached bitterness that avoids astringence. Typically well done through and through.

Aroma:caramel,very nutty,chocolate...
Appearance:dark brown,good beige head...
Flavor:caramel,nutty,good bitterness.chocolate...
I think this imperial brown ale is a scotch ale......

Not what youre looking for, if youre a fan of mild British brown ales. This is actually quite hoppy and very full bodied. Good looking reddish brown colour with a quite solid foamy head. Aroma and flavour dominated by roasted malts, chocolate and a bit of nuts. For some reason I thought this to be almost stout-like - perhaps because of the bitter aftertaste and the very full, smooth body.
Interesting and very well made beer.

My Bottom Line:
Elaborate caramel and nuttiness travels into teriyaki territory, a luxurious maltiness which gently sweeps into a grassy supporting hoppiness. A creamy, flavorful, classy strong Brown Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-Frothy foam settles atop the russet brown.
-Roastiness and toastiness add crunch.
-The fiery carbonation improves after letting the glass breathe, letting the wondrous malt shine through.
-The finishing bitterness isnt too important, but it dries up the malty sweetness nicely.
-Light citrusy fruitiness peeks through the bittering hop presence.

Bottle; best before March 09.

50 cl bottle. Reddish brown colour with a nice fine head. Sweet alcoholic aroma with notes of nuts-like. Sweet flavour of alcohol, caramel and toffee. Nice but nothing overwelming, maybe to alcoholic, but ends with a nice and tasty finish.
Dark red brown with a light brown head. Exciting roast grain and leather aromas. Roast and bitter flavour with a hint of warming alcohol. Lasting aftertaste, bitter and roasted.

Deep ruby-brown in colour, long lasting beige coloured head, great thick lacing.  The aroma is of bran muffins, fresh roast, chocolate, cookies, cake and dark fruits.  The flavour is of chocolate, some coffee, christmas cake, dark fruits, nutty, quite roasty, moderate sweetness.  Incredibly smooth and creamy mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long, rich, smooth.  Incredible Brown Ale.
500ml bottle from <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/denmark/ target=blank>Ølbutikken in Copenhagen, Denmark.
Best Before March 3, 2009.
Batch #237.

Mahogany red with a nice head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and so does the flavour. The mouthfeel is oily. I get notes of licorice, caramel, fruit and a nice bitterness. There isnt much sweetness, not more than the caramel notes give, and this makes it different from other BAs but this is an imperial - and a very nice one indeed!
Bottle at RBESG06, Hint of belguim, a lot of alcohol, a little nutty and rosted taste.

500 ml bottle. Dark brown and a little cloudy. Creamy light brown head. Marzipany and nutty aroma. Nutty and roasted malts.Toffee and caramel. Alcohol is noticeable as the burnt malts and the roasted flavours cannot quite compete. There is a bit of complex residual sugars, but the beer is mostly dry and thus lack a little to balance the alcohol. Finishes with a drying hop bitterness and burnt caramel.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown with a decent khaki head. Chocolate and roasted malts aroma with quite a bit of dark fruit.Good bitterness throughout meeting dark chocolate and fruit. Full-bodied with some alcohol.A big beer.
Bottle. Light brown high creamy and lasting head. Hazy dark red body. Caramel cocoa aroma. First smooth and sweet cocoa flavor ending however surprisingly bitter and sour on the tongue.
Pours a dark red/brown with a tanned frothey head leaving nice lacings. Tastes sweet and bready. Full bodied. Aromas of dark fruits with quite a bit of alcohol. Also a hint of nuts.

Dark brown color; huge thick head. The aroma has some caramel, but its lacking. Medium bodied beer, with a very strong caramel taste, a lot of malt and some liquorice too; high bitterness (good quality), but a bit metallic at the end. Overall, a powerful and good brew, without doubts.

Bottle. Deep amber,red colour, with a thick nice head.
Aroma of coffee,toffe,and lots of maltyness.
Palate is almost the same, but it has a complexity who is new from the Brewery I think. Citric, and a long nice finish. Without the typical Casade hops in the end. Werry nice Beer!!
Brown ale meets barley wine. Strong, round malty taste, not as hoppy as their other premium brews.

[Sampled at RGESG 2006]
Amber with a beige head.
Fresha dn hoppy aroma.
Really malty flavour with chocolate.
Dark brown color, off-white head. Weak aroma of roasted malt, some chocolate, licorice, bit alcohol. Bit sweet and malty taste, little sharpness in palate of alcohol. Becomes better during the drink.
Aroma of roasted chocolate malt. Bit weak aroma. Hazy, dark brown coloured with a lasting, off-white head. Taste is sweet, chocolate malty roasted. Some sugar. Light bodied. Nice.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2007 (Bottle) Pours red/brown with a small white head. A bit stale aroma with some iron and chocolate.  Sweet. Flavour is  pretty light with chocolate and a  peppery touch. A bit salty and really sweet. Brown ale sucks!
Dark mahogany redish. Malty, sugary, slight hoppy nose. Sugary, sweet and somewhat alcoholic flavour. Slight nutty.
[bottle at RBESG] Lots of caramel sweetness, nutty, toffee. Full bodied, sweet, warming finish.

Bottled. Dark brown with a huge sticky yellowish light brown head. Rather neutral and malty aroma of nuts and toffee. malty sweet flavour with touches of toasted malt, nuts and sweet licorice. Medium bitter aftertaste of nuts and grass with sweet vinous undertones.
Alround malty choco sort of sweetness. a bit one dimentional, not the best.
Amber, very nice offwhite head. Great malty aroma, nutty, butter and toffee notes. Malty flavor but also a bit vinous and a bit strong.

[Bottle]
Brown colour, off-white head. Sweetish nose with a prune accent. Chocolatey tone in flavour. Pretty thin. Long finish though. Big disappointment.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2006 Tried the beer again from bottle at RBESG 2006. I liked it better this time.
Clear dark red brown color, tan head. Chocolate malt and hops in the scent. Smooth mouth feel, low bitterness. Small malty and some alcohol taste.
First rating from beginngin of August: (Sampled from bottle, thanks Marsiblursi) Red color, creamy tan head. Fruity a bit chocolate scent. Bitter hoppy taste. Normal mouthfeel. Bitter and chocolate aftertaste. Normal to medium high bitterness.5/3/4/3/8 = 2.3
bottle. very dark amber color. large head. roasted malt aroma. roasted liqerice. some dark fruits. bit carpy.

Bottle shared with Mette at Amager Strandpark yesterday evening. Clear dark brown - offwhite head. Roasted, nuts, sweet, dried fruits, caramel, toffee, hop. Lovely - but I dont remember it this powerfull.

Dark brown, beige head; Quite powerful nose, some sharpness from alcohol, soft chocolate from malt, fresh citrus from hop; Soft textured body with fresh acidity, balanced; Finishes with aromas of melon, ripe grapefruit, malty soft chocolate, very long and complex, very hoppy fresh for a brown ale.

Bottle. Brown with a shade of red and a huge beige head. Malt, raisins, vanilla - almost smells a bakery of port cookies. Taste is sweet with hints of cookies, malt, licorice and a bit of metal. Nice beer this one...
Bottle. Brown and reddish in colour with a tan head. Malty and sweet - slightly roasted. Notes of caramel and spices.
Bottle. Weak, roasted, dusty aroma. Clear dark brown colour. Very small light brown head. OK roasted flavour, a little pepper bite. Quite pleasant, but not as flavourful as expected. Well-balanced.
Bottle. Hazy brown colour with a longlasting tan head. Roasted malty aroma with hints of caramel. Sweet malty flavor with hints of caramel and chocolate. Sweet malty aftertaste.

Deep dark red brown barely translucent body. Big beige creamy lasting head. Light sweet bready aroma. Very balanced, but not really that strong. Taste is deep, sweet, tight toffeeish licorice with spicy notes. Smooth and dense. Bitter marzipan nougat aftertaste, with bitter nougat lingering. Chewy, and yet somehow a bit watery after a while. Lovely! One of the best Nøgne Ø beers Ive had. (0.5l bottle at Cardinal.)

Huge light brown head that quickly disappated. Light brown color, but has an weak minerally nose.  Med-full body with thick syrupy sweet chocolate flavors. I found this a bit off balance. Sweet malty finish, with a bit of nuttiness. Interesting, but still a work in progress IMO.

[Bottled at Københavnske Øldage] Ruby. Small creamy head. Surprisingly neutral aroma. Sweet with a really solid body. Theres molasses and and intense flavours of roasty malt. When the flavours opens up it reveals cookie malt and licorice. Salty finish. I much prefer the non-imperialized version.

Cloudy brown colour with a nice beige head. Very sweet brown beer with lots of nutty malts, toffee, and chocolats (did I note oak/vanilla too?). The end is sweet, dry, and bitter. Good beer but is seems a little unbalanced (too sweet).

Unclear dark brown colored with a foamy lasting tan head. Dark roasted malty and grassy aroma with a vague spice and chocolate note. Flavor is roasted as well with a noticeable alcohol tone and some spicy bitterness in the finish. Pretty full but rather sharp on the palate. Good one but maybe a tad unbalanced.

Bottle: Deep reddish brown colour with a small light brown head. malty, light roasted aroma with caramel and nutty notes. Light roasted, caramel sweet flavor. Dry sweet finish with a weak hoppy bitterness.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a big beige head. Malty, Nutty, hoppy aroma and taste, light sweet.Medium to full body with a light sweet, dry finish.
Bottled. Red brown colour with a light brown head. Harmonic roasted  malt and caramel. Flavour is malt roasted caramel and hops. Rosted bitter finish.

Bottle. Toffee, nuts and caramel, with a warming finish, and some light fizz (which softens as it settles). Touches of licorice and brown sugar. Quite malty, as i guess it should be. Interesting concept. More drinkable than most normal strength brown ales ive had.

Bottled (Nøgne Ø Imperial Brown): Reddish brown coloured. UNClear. Dense light brown head. Nutty, herbal and fruity aroma. Flavour of brown sugar and liqourice. Malty and fruity. Has a touch of herbal notes. Is light sweet. Very smooth and medium bodied. Ends on a light bitter note. Is a bit more balanced than the Nørrebro version IMO.

Bottle.
Hazy orange brown coloured with an off white head.
Aroma of malts, fruits and nuts with notes of alcohol.
Roasted flavour of malts, fruits, nuts and hops.
Hoppy finish.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 500ml bottle. Deep, dark mahogany colour with nice reddish head. Very rich appealing aroma of malt, caramel and grass. Flavour is also very rich and warm. Plenty of malt with a balanced  element of roast, hops, nuts, coffee and dried prunes. A long pleasant finish with a warming hint of alcohol.  A fabulous beer.

500 ml bottle conditioned, courtesy of Cardinal, Stavanger (Norways best beer bar, untill someone proves me wrong, see Places section). Sampled side-by-side with its "sister brew", Nørrebro Bryghus Double Knot Brown Ale (pasteurised and unfiltered keg, see separate rating). ABV is 7.5%, 19 degrees Plato, 40 IBU. Very dark brown colour, moderate head. Darker than Nørrebro DKBA. Lovely malty aroma with plenty of aromatic hops, notes of chocolate and leather too. Rich and roasty flavour, plenty of malts and oak. Roasty long aftertaste. Excellent beer!

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Bottled. The brewers at Nøgne Ø made a guestbrew at Nørrebro Bryghus, and when they got home, they made their own version of it. This is the very good result. It is dark reddish-brown with a dense, tan head. The nose is light roasted, caramel, malt, hops and some alcohol. It has a light burnt fruitiness in the flavor, along with nuts, dried fruit, alcohol, coffee and chocolate. Medium to full bodied, and a finish with some alcohol and a dry, roasted coffee-like touch. A nice and balanced beer. (060406)
